title: Use FCMP implementation of BP+ in monero-serai

labels.name: monero
labels.description: An issue with the Monero library/integration

labels.name: cryptography
labels.description: An issue involving cryptography/a cryptographic library

body:
The implementation of BP+ from my work on FCMPs for Monero (https://github.com/kayabaNerve/full-chain-membership-proofs) is written to be extremely close to the paper and exceptionally clear. It's also had a good amount of effort spent on optimizations. While those optimizations were mainly for the arithmetic circuit code, this implementation still appears decently faster than the prior impl.

This adds a BP+ impl not descended from Monero's own, and can much more easily be used to verify Monero's impl matches the paper (as it was an effectively clean-room impl successfully modified to match, without any notable changes).

title: monero-serai: fee calculation parity with Monero's wallet2

labels.name: monero
labels.description: An issue with the Monero library/integration

body:
The goal of this PR is to ensure `monero-serai` constructs transactions using fees that are indistinguishable from Monero's wallet2. This PR accomplishes this goal to the best of my knowledge. I haven't tested it with mainnet yet but plan on doing so (while working on the decoy selection algorithm next).

The core internal difference this PR introduces to `monero-serai` transaction construction logic is that decoys must be selected *before* first calculating the fee. This is because a ring's `key_offsets` can vary in byte length between decoy selection attempts. By fixing the selected decoys at the start of tx construction, the tx builder can immediately calculate the tx's weight, calculate the fee based on that weight, and settle on the user's change.

Of note, there is a theoretical discrepancy to wallet2 that I noted in a comment in the function `calculate_weight_and_fee`. This discrepancy should never apply in practice. In short, wallet2 can theoretically use an estimate that is significantly different from what the calculated tx fee should be, which could cause wallet2 to use a fee that is not calculated from the final tx's weight. This does not occur in practice to the best of my knowledge; wallet2 *always* under-estimates the fee today by a small margin (it could have happened in the past when there were very few outputs in the chain). The reason I kept this theoretical discrepancy in `monero-serai` is because handling it would require copying brittle code from wallet2 that has oddities (and what look like bugs) that would be a pain to integrate cleanly for no practical gain (e.g. wallet2 does not factor in the expected final weight of tx extra in its initial estimate, while the CLI, RPC, and GUI do factor in the estimated weight of a payment ID in tx extra only if sending to an integrated address).

title: [Draft] Slash malevolent validators
body:
This is a **draft** pr to slash validators with bad behavior. Comments and/or reviews are appreciated.

in tributary, tendermint is used for the consensus. And there are bunch of defined invalid or bad behaviors for validators that participate in the tendermint consensus algorithm. We slash those nodes to disincentive those behaviors.

In this case, once a node catches an invalid/bad behavior from another validator, it either sends an evidence for this bad  behavior or a vote to slash the bad node. If an evidence provided and valid, it is solely enough to slash the node by the network participants even if other nodes didn't see this behavior. Once the evidence is on the chain, the bad node is slashed. If a vote is sent, then we wait vote from 2/3 of the nodes to slash the node.

For now following points are completed;

- create a special tx type to publish bad validator behavior data and/or votes for slashing
- modify the tributary to hold the both app txs and this integral tx
- ignore unsigned tendermint tx replays
- verify that provided evidence was actually valid(sender isn't falsely try to claim someone else with invalid evidence).
- scan the slash evidence/votes in the chain
- support unsigned app txs while at it(not really related to this pr but hey! why not)
- enforce provided, unsigned, signed tx ordering within a block
- add unit tests for tendermint tx validation
- update existing mempool/blockchain tests for new tx types

title: Initial In Instructions pallet and Serai client lib
body:
Exceeds its initial scope of the In Instructions pallet, and the stated additional scope of a Serai client lib, by additionally doing cleanup and infra work.

Does not complete the II pallet, which has to call other pallets, yet this code is currently required elsewhere, hence this PR existing now.

Defines a horrific InInstructionsProvider, which polls a JSON RPC server, to be replaced by Kafka.

Uses the `serai-client` lib to define e2e node tests.

Modularizes the processor tests, due to the history of this branch not currently reflected by this PR, with the caveat the processor currently uses `src/tests` when it should just use `tests/`. That'll be corrected after this is merged to develop.

title: Move to dtolnay/toolchain
body:
actions-rs/toolchain is unmaintained (https://github.com/actions-rs/toolchain/issues/216).

actions-rs will stop working in a few months thanks to the deprecation of `set-output` and NodeJS 12 (https://github.com/actions-rs/toolchain/issues/219 and https://github.com/actions-rs/toolchain/issues/221, respectively).

This moves to https://github.com/dtolnay/rust-toolchain, which is maintained, and deletes cached-rust per commentary in https://github.com/dtolnay/rust-toolchain/issues/26. We may later want to add https://github.com/Swatinem/rust-cache/ in.

title: FROST Ed448

labels.name: cryptography
labels.description: An issue involving cryptography/a cryptographic library

body:
Enables having an FROST library implementing all officially specified ciphersuites in the FROST spec, independently verifying its work while also ensuring the complete accuracy of ours.

Technically not FROST Ed448 as the FROST spec is malformed. This matches my open PR https://github.com/cfrg/draft-irtf-cfrg-frost/pull/246.

The Ed448 library is horrible. There's a reason the multiexp isn't run against it. It's only feasible for basic tests under release with vartime for some reason. It needs to be made acceptably performant, even under debug, AND drop the vartime backend to become safe. Then it'll set around as unaudited, yet it'll at least be constant time.

title: Conditional negate
body:
Now this is a mere draft. ~I think I might be missing something like the part around `ConditionallySelectable` in `lib.rs`~ Apparently I'm fine?.

This will look cleaner once #87 is merged.

@kayabaNerve If you'd like to take a look at this implicit approach fulfilling
```rust
impl<'a> Neg for &'a FieldElement
```
from https://docs.rs/subtle/2.4.1/subtle/trait.ConditionallyNegatable.html#impl-ConditionallyNegatable ?

I do not know whether this is better than explicitly implementing it like eg. this:

```rust
fn conditional_negate(&mut self, negate: Choice) {
    self.conditional_assign(&(-(*self)), negate);
}
```

Your choice.

title: Add implementation for `sqrt_ratio_i()`
body:
> in dalek-ff-group

`cargo fmt` and `clippy` are silent,
tests are fine.

Had no need for `conditional_negate` so I left it out for now, might add it later.

> Shouldn't that be a CtOption though?

_Originally posted by @kayabaNerve in https://github.com/dalek-cryptography/curve25519-dalek/issues/389#issuecomment-1212682725_

This matches the function definition of curve25519-dalek, so it returns `(Choice, FieldElement)`.

I haven't seen a conflicting Trait that specifies it to be `CtOption`.

title: Add multiple variants to cross-group DLEq and clean the code
body: A comprehensive README establishing the different variants and their size/performance has also been added, with multiple notes it isn't formally proven nor audited. The `cross_group` feature has also been renamed `experimental_cross_group`.

title: Add first-party support for Ristretto, ed25519, secp256k1, and P-256
body:
Extends dalek-ff-group into a macro'd solution implemented for both Ristretto and Ed25519.

Removes our expand_xmd for elliptic-curve's.

secp256k1 doesn't currently have a ciphersuite, so P-256 is mirrored with a new context string, as secp256k1 does have the same hash to field (beyond the context string).

I didn't want to do this previously, as dalek-ff-group has unimplemented methods, yet they're all explicitly unimplemented as of now and all constants should be fully valid.

Ristretto replaces P-256 as the curve used for testing the FROST crate.

title: Remove monero-rs types
body:
Preserves monero-rs, for now, for its Address encoding functionality and Extra encoding. Both should be minor to remove at a later point as this PR is already quite notable.

Fixes #1 and allows progress on #2, and therefore progress on using unique shared keys.
